description: From Middle English god, from Old English god, originally neuter, then changed to masculine to reflect the change in religion to Christianity, from Proto-West Germanic *god n, from Proto-Germanic *gudą, from *ǵʰutóm, neuter/inanimate of Proto-Indo-European *ǵʰutós (“invoked (one)”), from Proto-Indo-European *ǵʰewH- (“to call, to invoke”) or *ǵʰew- (“to pour”). Not related to the word good or Persian خدا‎ (xodâ, “god”).
Cognates include Russian звать (zvatʹ, “to call”), Sanskrit होत्र (hotra, “calling, oblation, sacrifice”) and Latin fūtilis (“easily pours out, leaky”) (whence English futile). Doublet of futile.

entries.meaning: A deity or supreme being; a supernatural, typically immortal, being with superior powers, to which personhood is attributed.
examples: The most frequently used name for the Islamic god is Allah.

entries.meaning: A representation of a deity, especially a statue or statuette.
Something or someone particularly revered, worshipped, idealized, admired and/or followed.
(figurative, slang) A person who is exceptionally skilled in a particular activity.
examples: He is the god of soccer!

entries.meaning: (figurative) A person in a high position of authority, importance or influence.

examples: Lounging on the beach were several Greek gods.

entries.meaning: (Internet, role-playing games) The person who owns and runs a multi-user dungeon.

verbs.description: god (third-person singular simple present gods, present participle godding, simple past and past participle godded)

examples: To men the first necessity is gods; / And if the gods were not, / " Man would invent them, tho' they godded stones.
Then got he bow and fhafts of gold and lead, / In which fo fell and puiflant he grew, / That Jove himfelfe his powre began to dread, / And, taking up to heaven, him godded new.
